Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.raw_text: Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, and the common law covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in leases, a landlord must not substantially interfere with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of leased premises and must take reasonable steps to remedy conditions that substantially impair habitability and the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (recognizing implied warranty of habitability and landlord obligations) (persuasive authority);
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses and expressly adopts an implied warranty of habitability in all residential leases, detailing landlords’ obligations to provide and maintain safe, clean, and fit premises, and the remedies available to tenants. It rejects the old caveat lessee/constructive eviction framework, treats the lease as a contract with interdependent covenants of habitability and rent, and discusses landlord liability and tenant remedies. This directly supports citing the case as persuasive authority on the implied warranty of habitability and landlord obligations.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. This warranty of habitability is implied in tenancies for a specific period or at will… Additionally, the implied warranty of habitability covers all latent and patent defects in the essential facilities of the residential unit.”
